utterances: How did you get into poker?
A bunch of us played softball together.
And we quit playing softball and started playing cards.
Well, when you got back to Oakland, Maryland, you know, back to see your friends that you normally play poker with, did they treat you any differently?
No. They all still call me a donkey and tell me I'm a terrible card player and...
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
...it's all the same.
Is it sort of strange that all these people fuss over you and probably call you, you know, Mr. Moon and all these things?
Yeah.
Yeah, that's a little different.
It's - you go in a restaurant and everybody is, you know, talking to you.
And I like to go in a restaurant, sit down and eat, and get up and leave...
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
...and nobody even recognizes you.
That don't happen any more.
I read that you actually took some of your winnings and helped fix up your parents' home.
Yeah, I put a new roof on their home.
There's a little church in our community, I think there's like 20 people that attend that church.
There's a couple people that are older.
And the parking lot was like gravel and they have trouble walking, so I paved the parking lot at the church.
Just little things like that.
I mean, a lot of people might say, Darvin, if you win eight and half million bucks, you don't ever have to work another day in your life.
Don't have to, but I'm going to.
You're going to go right back to work.
Right back to work, yeah.
No doubt about it.
What about your wife, Wendy?
She works every day.
So even if you come home with a big cash prize, she'll still go to work.
That's my plan.
Hmm.
Is that her plan?
I don't know what her plan is...
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
...but that's my plan.
She still works.
Do you have any ritual that you do before you play, you know, for good luck?
No.
So you don't wear, like, the same socks for a week?
No.
I wear the same hat, other than that, I change clothes.
What kind of hat is it?
A New Orleans Saints.
New Orleans Saints, so you're a Saints fan?
Yeah.
They're going to win the Super Bowl.
I'm going to win the World Series of Poker.
Me and the New Orleans Saints will have a little party, and we'll go out and have a steak or something.
And I'm assuming that you'll buy for everybody.
I think if they win the damn Super Bowl, they ought to be buying for me, you know?
I think their salaries are a little above mine.
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
That's Darvin Moon.
I spoke with him before he left for Las Vegas from the site of his logging operation in Oakland, Maryland.
He went into today's World Series of Poker's final table as its chip leader.
In the occupied West Bank this week, Israeli authorities forcibly evacuated an illegal outpost established by a group of Jewish settlers.
The settlers responded with an attack on nearby Palestinian property.
As NPR's Lourdes Garcia-Navarro reports, it's a tactic the settlers are calling the price tag.
Ahmed Ghanem's fields and olive orchard lie just between the Jewish settlements of Kedumim and Yitzhar in the northern part of the West Bank.
Last Sunday, Israeli police evicted a group of settlers who had established a small illegal outpost near one of the settlements.
A few hours later, some 20 settlers set fire to Ghanem's orchard, he says.
Standing on a craggy outcrop, the Palestinian farmer surveys the damage.
(Foreign language spoken)
It's the olive harvest season now, he says, and the attack couldn't have happened at a worst time.
(Through Translator) They managed to burn my land and the land of my neighbor, and they burned 150 trees.
Ghanem says there's little he can do to protect his property.
(Through Translator) The settlers can do whatever they want.
I am helpless.
Ghanem was the victim of a new tactic extremist settler groups call the price tag.
Each time an illegal settler outpost is evacuated by Israeli authorities, the settlers retaliate with an attack on Palestinian land or property.
We've been monitoring this in Yesh Din for the last, at least, I think a year.
Michael Sfard is a lawyer who works with Israeli human rights group, Yesh Din
Oh, it's quite smart but evil.
The security forces will have to divert the resources, manpower and energy to deal with the new problem.

According to a Palestinian Authority official who deals with the settlements issue, since the beginning of the year, 3,400 trees have been destroyed in settler attacks in just this part of the West Bank.
Sfard says the tactic works.
Because of the settler attacks, he says, Israeli courts are now more reluctant to approve petitions for the evacuation of illegal outposts.
I mean, the court tells me time and again: You know that it's not that simple to do what you're asking.
And I'm always saying: Well, it means that being violent turns out to be a very clever thing to do.
A day after the attack on Ghanem's orchard, a group of settlers were back at the outpost that had been evacuated by Israeli authorities.
The detritus of their scuffle with the police lay scattered on the ground.
Nineteen-year-old Yishai Gilad says the Jews have the right to the land here.
